Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

In this Problem, students use all of the methods or tools they have learned (coins, number cubes, blocks, and spinners) to evaluate the fairness of an activity. Students must use what they have already learned to decide if their chosen strategy is fair and how to use that strategy to create a fair event.

Suggested questions

  • What does it mean to choose fairly? (Everyone has an equally likely chance of being chosen. The choosing is done randomly.)

Presenting the Challenge

Explain the situation in the Introduction on choosing a messenger to send to the office. Ask students if they have any suggestions to fairly select a student. Have students work in groups of two to three. For the Initial Challenge you might want to divide up the possible methods to investigate and have each group analyze two to three methods to save time. Have available blank spinners (Learning Aid 3.1: Blank Spinner), number cubes, coins, colored, blocks, straws, and bags for students who want to test their ideas.

Implementation Note: You might want to have a brief conversation after the Initial Challenge before having groups work on the What If Situations.
